instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message:
*Title should be <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>*

This otherwise functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board won't turn on when the battery is plugged (with or without the power adapter plugged in). Known-good battery. Voltage is going to the board normally, same as a known-good logic board. PPBUS on both boards is at 11.4V with just battery plugged in.

Board was liquid-damaged. I attached pre-ultrasonic pictures.

I've seen this before but I'm not sure what's happening. Something on the board is telling it not to turn on.

The 6 pins on the connector are measuring the exact same in diode mode as a known-good board.

Any ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] Hey Louis, do you have any ideas about this? This seems to be something with the newer boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: So the board only auto powers on? Is the power button working?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: It works normally with the power button with the adapter plugged in. You can shut it down, turn it on with the power button, everything normal, but as soon as I plug in that battery cable, it won't turn on. I checked and cleaned up everything around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. All pads are good and measurements all match a good board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: Battery recognized in OSX and charging?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: It won't turn on with the battery plugged in.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: Only thing I can see that  may cause an issue would be <SIGNAL>BMON_IOUT</SIGNAL>. <RESISTOR>R5679</RESISTOR> got corroded? Got another board to compare voltages?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5679</RESISTOR> is not on the Touch Bar boards. The whole <CHIP>U5710</CHIP> area is basically No Stuff. <SIGNAL>BMON_IOUT</SIGNAL> has nothing actually in the circuit. <RESISTOR>R5679</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U5710</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R5675</RESISTOR> were all left off of this board. Any other thoughts? There seems to be some sort of signal telling the board to stay off once I plug in the battery, some type of sensor or safety feature.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: I'm not sure. Could be the system measures current draw with <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR>. Was there any liquid there? Checked the resistors and traces there?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: There was some corrosion at <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR>. I replaced them along with <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>. No change. Traces and pads are all good. Continuity is good on all the lines. <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> seems fine. It's hard to measure it because it's so low, but it's not blown open. Do you every have any luck replacing that main sense resistor on other boards? I'm not sure if I've ever fixed a board replacing that main resistor.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: The main resistor will be fine. Is it possible crap got under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: It looks like <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> might be damaged. I measured the 40 points underneath it and all are good except 27 - <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. It should be .589 in diode mode and it's at .088. I pulled <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. No change. The balls around the edge of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are very visible and look clean. I've run a whole lot of flux underneath it. No change. I haven't replaced an <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> yet. I have a donor board I can pull one from, not sure it's going back on though. I ordered some from Louis, so I'll use those if I can't reball this one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: I'm worried that they may have firmware just like the <CHIP>ISL95530</CHIP> on the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards. You can try Louis's chip first to confirm this. If it does not work then be very careful and save the donor chip as it will be your only chance to fix this.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: How would it play out if that's the case? Would the chip just not work?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: No idea on these boards yet. On the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards PPBUS will just not come up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: Ok thanks, I got it going. I used a <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. I've never done a BGA chip that big without reballing it first. It was a little tricky but it's working fine with all 40 points measuring correctly. Works on battery and adapter. Charging normally. Thanks for your help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: Oh I hoped you would try a new chip so we could know if that works. Anyway it is fixed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't turn on with battery plugged in.
threads.message: Yes, and it would have been a lot easier with solder balls on the chip. I'm sure we'll find out soon enough though if the new chips work. I'll update you once I try using one of them.
